OpenGWAS

Brian M. Schilder

2021-07-14

Source: vignettes/OpenGWAS.Rmd
OpenGWAS.Rmd
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = T, root.dir=here::here())
knitr::opts_knit$set(root.dir=here::here())

library(MungeSumstats)

Query and import data from the MRC IEU Open GWAS Project.

Find GWAS datasets

#### Search for datasets ####
metagwas <- MungeSumstats::find_sumstats(traits = c("parkinson","alzheimer"), 
                                         min_sample_size = 5000)
## Collecting metadata from Open GWAS.
## Filtering metadata by substring criteria.
## Filtering metadata by sample/case/control/SNP size criteria.
## Excluding sample/case/control size with NAs.
## Found 16 GWAS datasets matching search criteria across:
##    - 12 trait(s)
##    - 1 population(s)
##    - 3 category(ies)
##    - 2 subcategory(ies)
##    - 5 publication(s)
##    - 6 consortia(ium)
##    - 1 genome build(s)
head(metagwas)
## # A tibble: 6 x 22
##   id     trait    group_name  year consortium      author sex   population unit 
##   <chr>  <chr>    <chr>      <int> <chr>           <chr>  <chr> <chr>      <chr>
## 1 ieu-a… Alzheim… public      2013 IGAP            Lambe… Male… European   log …
## 2 ieu-b… Alzheim… public      2019 Alzheimer Dise… Kunkl… Male… European   NA   
## 3 ieu-a… Alzheim… public      2013 IGAP            Lambe… Male… European   log …
## 4 ebi-a… Alzheim… public      2013 NA              Lambe… NA    European   logOR
## 5 ebi-a… Family … public      2018 NA              Mario… NA    European   NA   
## 6 ukb-b… Illness… public      2018 MRC-IEU         Ben E… Male… European   SD   
## # … with 13 more variables: sample_size <int>, nsnp <int>, build <chr>,
## #   category <chr>, subcategory <chr>, ontology <chr>, note <chr>, mr <int>,
## #   pmid <int>, priority <int>, ncase <int>, ncontrol <int>, sd <dbl>
ids <- (dplyr::arrange(metagwas, nsnp))$id[1:2]

Import full results

datasets <- MungeSumstats::import_sumstats(ids = ids)

Summarise results

By default, import_sumstats results a named list where the names are the Open GWAS dataset IDs and the items are the respective paths to the formatted summary statistics.

print(datasets)
## $`ieu-a-298`
## [1] "/var/folders/zq/h7mtybc533b1qzkys_ttgpth0000gn/T//RtmpA6fkpm/ieu-a-298.tsv.gz"
## 
## $`ieu-a-812`
## [1] "/var/folders/zq/h7mtybc533b1qzkys_ttgpth0000gn/T//RtmpA6fkpm/ieu-a-812.tsv.gz"

You can easily turn this into a data.frame as well.

results_df <- data.frame(id=names(datasets), 
                         path=unlist(datasets))
print(results_df)
##                  id
## ieu-a-298 ieu-a-298
## ieu-a-812 ieu-a-812
##                                                                                    path
## ieu-a-298 /var/folders/zq/h7mtybc533b1qzkys_ttgpth0000gn/T//RtmpA6fkpm/ieu-a-298.tsv.gz
## ieu-a-812 /var/folders/zq/h7mtybc533b1qzkys_ttgpth0000gn/T//RtmpA6fkpm/ieu-a-812.tsv.gz

Import full results (parallel)

Optional: Speed up with multi-threaded download via axel.

datasets <- MungeSumstats::import_sumstats(ids = ids, 
                                           vcf_download = TRUE, 
                                           download_method = "axel", 
                                           nThread = max(2,future::availableCores()-2))
